abstract.$: "The garden of Horikiri is exclusively devoted to the cultivation of the iris.  There you may see its many varieties, from white through all the shades of mauve and lilac to purple, and to a blue that is almost black, so deep it is.  In the beginning of June a continual stream of sightseers threads it way with one object in view--the iris garden, and in the garden besides the flowers are to be found all sorts of little souvenirs on which the iris is painted, to be carried home as momentoes of the visit."--printed on verso.

physicalLocation.$: The Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Division of Art, Prints and Photographs: Picture Collection

namePart.$: Du Cane, Ella (British painter and illustrator, born in Australia, 1874-1943)

note.$: "Souvenir--Japan-British Exhibition 1910. 'Flowers and Gardens of Japan' Series II. Raphael Tuck & Sons' 'Oilette' postcard 7917. Art publishers to Their Majesties the King & Queen. From 'Japan,' illustrated by Ella Du Cane (A. & C. Black)."--printed on verso.
